_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Sunoco Partners Marketing and Terminals (Sunoco) Washington Terminal complies with the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) #58 (2004 Edition) for Liquified Petroleum Gas Storage, and it is the facility's policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state and local laws / codes.  If an emergency were to occur, it is the facility's policy to notify the Washington Fire Department as well as the Wilkes County LEPC, as necessary.  Medical emergencies will require notification of the Wilkes County Emergency Medical Service and Wills Memorial Hospital.  THis facility does not maintain a trained fire brigade or hazardous material response team on-site to respond to the initial stages of an emergency.  On-site personnel consist of truck transport drivers during off loading activities and period Sunoco Partners Marketing and Terminals representatives.



The Sunoco Partners Marketing and Terminals - Washinton Terminal is a butane transfer facility (specifically, rail car to trauck transfer tanker).  This Risk Management Plan (RMP) covers the butane transfer systems only, including the associated piping and eight (8) 31,000 - gallon storage tanks (railcars).  This is the maximum capacity of the railspur.  



This facility's worst case scenario is the catastrophic failure of one (1) 31,000 (butane capacity) - gallon storage tank car when filled to the greatest amount allowed resulting in a vapor cloud explosion.  The facility's alternate (most likely what could effect offsite receptors) scenario is a BLEVE incident involving one (1) railcar.  The resulting distance to the endpoint (5 kw/m2-40 sec.) effects public receptors.  THis scenario was selected based on the potential to impact receptors offsite (largest quantity released).



The Sunoco Partners Marketing and Terminals Washinton Terminal complies with the U.S. Environmental Protections Agency's (EPA) accident prevention tules (40 CFR Part 68 Subpart D), the Occupational Safety and Health Administration Operat

ions and Emergency Management Response (HAZWOPER) Standard (29 CFR Part 1910.120), and all applicable state and local codes and regulations.  This butane transfer system is designed, constructed and maintained in accordance with NFPA #58 as the manufacturers (Sunoco Partners Marketing and Terminals) instructions.



To date, this facility has never had as accident involving butane (approximately six(6) years old) which has resulted in deaths, injuries, property / environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in-place.



In the event of an emergency involving the Sunoco Partners Marketing and Terminals - Washington Terminal's butane transfer system, it is the policy of the facility to initially contact the Washington Fire Department and request their assistance.  The facility currently has no trained fire brigade or hazardous materials response team.  The facility emergency action plans are coordianted with the fire department and the Wilkes EMA.  The Washington Fire Department has participated in the initial RMP / PSM training session for this system.  



Planned changes to improve safety:



The Facility has completed a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) and subsequent updates/revalidations for this process and has developed an action plan for consideration.



Improvement actions to be considered primarily focus on site security measures including improved monitoring and inspection access.  Other considerations include improvements to minimize off-site migration of butane in the event of a release especially in the cold season.
